Whitney Houston (July 9, 1963 – February 11, 2012) was an American singer, songwriter, and actress whose powerful and emotive voice, coupled with her ability to perform a range of musical styles, earned her the title of the "Queen of Soul." Born in Newark, New Jersey, she was raised in the Houston area of Texas. Houston rose to fame as a recording artist, television personality, and fashion model.

Houston's career began as a child, singing on local radio and television. She later auditioned for the girl group The Sweet Inspirations and eventually became the lead singer. Houston's breakout performance came in 1984 with the release of her self-titled debut album, which featured the hit single "You Give Good Love." This success launched her into the international music scene and set the stage for a series of hit albums, including "Whitney," "I'm Your Baby Tonight," and "The Bodyguard: Original Soundtrack Album."

Throughout her career, Houston received multiple Grammy, Emmy, and Billboard Music Awards, becoming one of the best-selling recording artists of all time. Her signature song "I Will Always Love You," originally written and recorded by Dolly Parton, remains an enduring classic and has become synonymous with Houston's legacy.

Houston's success also extended into acting, with her most notable role in the 1992 film "The Bodyguard," for which she won an Academy Award for Best Original Song for "I Will Always Love You." She reprised the role in the film's sequel, "The Bodyguard: Backstage," in 2005.

Despite her immense success, Houston struggled with personal and professional challenges throughout her life. She battled substance abuse, and in 2010, she was arrested on charges of driving under the influence. Her untimely death in 2012, resulting from accidental drowning in a bathtub, sent shockwaves throughout the music world and brought her career achievements into sharp focus. Whitney Houston remains a lasting icon of the entertainment industry, and her music continues to inspire and influence artists worldwide.
